text: my name is Rebecca dqo I'm a research
data scientist at the Smithsonian
Institution
I'm Paul Frandsen I'm a research data
scientist in the Smithsonian Institution
in the data science lab so we have a
mass digitization program that is taking
objects and making 3d images or flat
images that we're doing that with our
Natural History collections and so we
have this wealth of data and so it made
sense instead of just looking at these
and verticals to have kind of a
horizontal approach to data science and
so we started this data science lab to
try to make insights about you know
connecting all these data together and
have better understanding of all the
processes that we're trying to study the
genomes that we work on at the
Smithsonian are often not assembled to
the chromosome level so we're left with
them being in hundreds or sometimes
thousands of pieces and so the
annotations are done on each of those
pieces individually and so what we can
do with AWS is send off each of the
processes in parallel and then bring
them back together at the end and that
often doesn't work well on HPC where you
don't a single user wouldn't have access
to thousands of compute cores on this
thing that at the same time so we can
really speed up the process of this
genome annotation using AWS we saw the
cloud as a perfect way for the tools
that we're developing to be able to
share those with other collaborators
around the world but also get other
collaborators involved with us so if
we're doing this sort of development in
a place that anybody can mimic the exact
kind of you know development landscape
you're looking at then we can also
include more people in our open research
some things about the cloud that we're
really appealing to us was the ability
to scale out to a large number of CPU
cores or instances for a short period of
time and
not have it cost a lot of money so we
can be really flexible and and how we
provision our instances so the benefits
we've seen in using the cloud are the
ability to share a.m. eyes with other
researchers as well as to be able to
scale out to thousands of thousands of
course really easily really I see it
about as kind of consolidating mental
resources or the software and things
like that but then also allowing us to
spread out our analysis over many more
you know compute resources at once
rather than have to sit in the queue and
wait for an HPC it's helped us you know
increase knowledge by making our
research go faster and then it's also
helped us diffuse it because it gives us
a place to share workflows to be open
about how we're doing our science and
how we're doing our data science and so
I think it fits in really well with what
we're trying to do at the Smithsonian
Institution at the data science lab
where were involved in lots of
biodiversity genomics questions and I
think moving to the cloud has allow us
allowed us to empower researchers to
really take on these genomics projects
and we're trying to enable that kind of
research and and moving to the cloud I
think is one way to to
do that
